item.title: Ticket #550 (Error with comment status in functions-comments.php with comment status) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #550 (Error with comment status in functions-comments.php with comment status) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: When posting an article without touching any of the default settings (having set default_comments_status and default_ping_status to zero using the checkboxes in the 'Discussion' tab), I'd often get a "Comments (0)" instead of a "Comments Off". This only happened when posting with the default options (simple, nothing touched). It seems what caused this was that the comment_status and ping_status values in the SQL database (wp_posts) were blank (set to the default '0') . In functions_comments.php, it only places a "comments off" value if comment_status and ping_status are set to "closed". To resolve this issue, I went to the options page (class=ALL) and set default_comment_status and default_ping_status to "closed". Again, the issue is in functions-comments.php as it only checks to see if the comment and ping status reads "closed" instead of both closed or zero.

item.title: Ticket #548 (sidebar archives link broken - get_month_link needs fixing) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #548 (sidebar archives link broken - get_month_link needs fixing) updated
item.dc:creator: DarkCryst
item.description: this is actually my bug report.. I forgot to log in.

item.title: Ticket #548 (sidebar archives link broken - get_month_link needs fixing) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #548 (sidebar archives link broken - get_month_link needs fixing) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I was having a problem with my sidebar archives links display as

​http://%url%%year%/%month% rather than ​http://%url%/%year%/%month%

I tracked it back to the function get_month_link in template-functions-links.php

I had to replace the line:

$monthlink = str_replace('%year%', $year, $monthlink); with $monthlink = str_replace('%year%', "/".$year, $monthlink);

and it worked smoothly from there on. I thought this was quite a wierd bug but I'm surprised its not come to light before. There may be another solution to this - but this was the quickest one I saw.

item.title: Ticket #546 (in_category() doesn't work above "the loop") closed
item.dc:creator: 2fargon

item.title: Ticket #546 (in_category() doesn't work above "the loop") updated
item.dc:creator: jonthejester
item.description:
Well... I decided to copy the following code from wp-blog-header.php in WP 1.2 and put it just below require('./wp-blog-header.php');:

if ($posts) {

foreach ($posts as $post) {

$post_id_list[] = $post->ID;

}

$post_id_list = implode(',', $post_id_list);

$dogs = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT DISTINCT

ID, category_id, cat_name, category_nicename, category_description, category_parent

FROM $tablecategories, $tablepost2cat, $tableposts

WHERE category_id = cat_ID AND post_id = ID AND post_id IN ($post_id_list)");

foreach ($dogs as $catt) {

$category_cache[$catt->ID][] = $catt;

}

}

The good news is that seems to kick in_category() into working above the loop. The bad news is that the category listing gets repeated. I guess that's obvious because of the way I'm calling the thing, as it is.

Could someone direct me as to how I (or anyone else) could code this into wp-blog-header.php, or just make it so that in_category will take it without a double listing of the category? This is illustrated at ​http://daysdifference.com.

edited on: 12-15-04 05:56

item.title: Ticket #546 (in_category() doesn't work above "the loop") updated
item.dc:creator: jonthejester
item.description:
Ok, if I understand this right, is it that the category_cache in 1.3 will get updated, and thus reflected, when the_post() (a.k.a. start_wp, "the loop") is called? And in 1.2, the category_cache being updated/reflected from the beginning, through if($posts) { } in wp-blog-header.php? Maybe this is why in_category() won't work before the_post() is called.

Any way to backport the category aspect (if it is category_cache) to wp-blog-header.php or something?

edited on: 12-14-04 18:27

item.title: Ticket #546 (in_category() doesn't work above "the loop") updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I decided to check out the function for in_category, in template-functions-category.php. It appears in_category() is the same code used in 1.3 as is used in 1.2.

To make a long story short, I found that $category_cache, which seems to be the problem variable, is used/defined in functions.php (line 1430) under WP 1.3 in contrast to wp-blog-header.php (line 479) under WP 1.2. However, at this point, I'm still somewhat slow in my understanding of PHP. Some help with translating what's different, what's causing the above-the-loop problem, would be nice. :)

(Thanks for changing the issue to "minor". Sorry about the "block" status on my part, I'm new here O:-))

(This is jonthejester, forgot to login)

edited on: 12-14-04 17:27

item.title: Ticket #546 (in_category() doesn't work above "the loop") created
item.dc:creator: jonthejester
item.description: In WP 1.3-alpha-5, in_category() doesn't work above posts loop; in_category() works in the posts loop and below the posts loop, but it doesn't work above. In WP 1.2, in_category() works above the posts loop, in addition to below and in the posts loop.

item.title: Ticket #545 (comments-popup.php is not read from the template directory) updated
item.dc:creator: Dinini
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #545 (comments-popup.php is not read from the template directory) created
item.dc:creator: Dinini
item.description:
8 December saw the introduction of TEMPLATEPATH and moving the user customised files out of the base directory into wp-content. Unfortunately comments-popup.php will neither load from the base directory nor the template directories.

The file used is determined in comments_popup_script(). As currently written it appears to be set to wp-comments-popup.php. If that were not the setting the test as written would be using the result of get_template_directory() (full local filepath) but the output of the function $wpcommentspopupfile is used to form the url for the link and won't work.
